column2: officially the City of Mandaluyong (Filipino: Lungsod ng Mandaluyong)
column3: is a 1st class highly urbanized city in Metropolitan Manila
column4: Philippines. According to the 2015 census
column5: it has a population of 386
column7: it is known for the Ortigas Center
column8: a commercial and business center that is also shared with the city of Pasig. Notable institutions and establishments in the city include the Asian Development Bank
column9: the headquarters of Banco De Oro and San Miguel Corporation and shopping malls like Shangri-La Plaza and SM Megamall.

column1: The city is bordered by Manila to the west
column2: San Juan to the north
column3: Quezon City to the northeast
column4: Pasig to the east
column5: and Makati to the south. It is also the 6th-smallest city in the Philippines with a land area of 11.06 km2 (4.27 sq mi).

column1: There are different stories on the origin of the name Mandaluyong.
One tells of how the place was abundant with a kind of tree called luyong
column2: now more commonly known as anahaw (Saribus rotundifolius)
column3: from which canes and furniture were made.

column1: Another claims that the Spaniards named the place based on the report of a navigator named Acapulco
column2: who saw the rolling hills frequently being lashed at by daluyong (“big waves from the sea”). This seems to confirm traditional pre-Hispanic stories that giant waves from the sea would meet the adjoining hills of the vast lowland
column3: referred to as salpukan ng alon. Felix dela Huerta
column4: a Franciscan historian
column5: observed that the rolling topography of this land resembled giant waves of the sea.

column1: As with the etymological legends of many Philippine places
column2: when the foreigners asked what the place was called
column3: the locals answered with the description "madaluyong" ("undulating")
column4: later transcribed by Spanish writers as "Mandaluyong
column5:
with the addition of an “n”.
Another version of the name is based on a legend that a Maharlika named Luyong fell in love with Manda, the lovely daughter of a barangay chieftain. The chieftain did not like Luyong and forbade him Manda's hand. Luyong overcame this objection by winning a series of tribal contests, as was the custom at the time. The couple settled thereafter in a place which was later called “Mandaluyong - a term made up of joining their names.

column1: Residents of Mandaluyong have always been known for their industry. Men did the laundry to the amusement of non-residents until shortly after the war
column2: while the women ironed the clothes.

column1: These industrious people trace their roots to Emperor Soledan (also known as “Anka Widyaya” of the Great Madjapahit Empire) and Empress Sasaban of the Kingdom of Sapa
column2: whose son Prince Balagtas ruled as sovereign of the kingdom in about the year 1300.
in about the year 1470
column3: it expanded and was called the “Kingdom of Namayan” with “Lakan Takhan” as sovereign. The vast Kingdom comprised what are now Quiapo
column4: San Miguel
column5: Sta
column10: Malate and Santa Ana in Manila
column18: and portions of Pasig and Quezon City up to Diliman
column19: which were then part of Mandaluyong.

column1: Mandaluyong was first known as a barrio of Santa Ana de Sapa
column2: which was part of the District of Paco
column3: Province of Tondo. Named San Felipe Neri by the Spaniards in honor of the patron saint of Rome
column4: it was separated civilly from Santa Ana de Sapa in 1841.

column1: On 15 September 1863 San Felipe Neri established its own parish. Under the administration of the Congregation “Dulcísimo Nombre de Jesús”
column2: it constructed its own church
column3: convent and school. The Parish of San Felipe Neri played a significant role as a relay station for propagating the Katipunan during the 1896–1898 Revolution.

column1: Mandaluyong was significant in the Philippine Revolution of 1896 as the baluarte (territory) of the Katipunan or "Makabuhay" group
column2: with seventeen (17) branches.
Andres Bonifacio
column3: together with Emilio Jacinto and other members of the Katipunan went into the house of Romualdo Vicencio at Sitio Balakbak (now Villa San Miguel) to prepare for the upcoming revolution against Spanish authority. In this site
column4: Bonifacio read the last manifestation of the Katipunan before they transferred in Hagdan Bato
column5: in the house of Felix Sanchez. This event is also known as the "29 De Agosto" and "Pinagtipunan" in which it is already named in two streets near the historic Barangay Hagdan Bato Itaas. It was in Barangay Hagdang Bato on 28 August 1896 where Andres Bonifacion issued a proclamation setting Saturday
column6: 29 August 1896 as the date of the attack on Manila.

column2: after the successfully revolution in San Felipe Neri
column3: the katipuneros went to San Juan del Monte and attacked the El Polvorin (gunpowder depot) in order to amass more weapons to use against the Spaniards. This event is popularly known as the Battle of San Juan del Monte.

column1: It was also in this town that the revolutionary paper
column2: “La Republika”
column3: was established on 15 September 1896.

column2: San Felipe Neri was raised to a first class municipality with five (5) barrios
column3: namely: Poblacion
column4: Barangka
column5: Hagdang Bato
column6: Namayan and Hulo. Under Presidential Act No. 942
column7: it was consolidated with the municipality of San Juan del Monte and became the seat of government. For several months in 1904
column8: San Felipe Neri became the capital of the province of Rizal.

column1: San Felipe Neri was separated from San Juan and became an independent municipality on 27 March 1907. It was renamed the Municipality of Mandaluyong by virtue of House Bill No. 3836 which was authored and sponsored by Assemblyman Pedro Magsalin
column2: then the Representative of the District of Rizal. Many government infrastructures are established during the American Period including the Correctional Institute for Women
column3: Welfareville Compound
column4: The Boy's Town
column5: and the National Center for Mental Health.

column2: Mandaluyong lost many of her people; among them were Catholic priests and civilians. Destruction was felt all over
column3: but with the timely arrival of the American Liberation Forces and the Philippine Commonwealth troops on 9 February 1945
column4: the municipality was saved from further damages. That day became a red calendar day for Mandaluyong marking its liberation from the Japanese Imperial forces by the Allies.

column2: Mandaluyong began to become progressive and dramatically increase the economy. Many infrastructures
column3: companies
column4: and other businesses were developed in 1950s–1960s and as the result
column5: Mandaluyong recognized as the most developed municipality in the Province of Rizal.

column2: Mandaluyong was formally included in newly established Metropolitan Manila by virtue of Presidential Decree No. 824 signed by President Ferdinand Marcos.

column1: By virture of the 1987 Constitution Mandaluyong and the then municipality of San Juan were represented in congress by a single Congressman.

Rep. Ronaldo Zamora sponsored a House Bill which eventually became Republic Act No. 7675 otherwise known as "An Act Converting the Municipality of Mandaluyong into a Highly Urbanized City to be known as the City of Mandaluyong." President Fidel V. Ramos signed R.A. No. 7675 into law on 9 February 1994 (the 49th anniversary of its liberation from the Japanese)
column2: which was ratified through a plebiscite on 10 April 1994 making Mandaluyong the 5th city in Metro Manila. Mandaluyong became a lone district with its own Representative in Congress. Prior to the enactment of the assailed statute
column3: the municipalities of Mandaluyong and San Juan belonged to only one legislative district.

column1: Mandaluyong today is composed of 27 barangays divided into two political districts mainly by Boni Avenue and G. Aglipay Street. As of 9 January 2002
column2: it has 1
column3: 238 voting precincts and a total of 166
column4: 037 registered voters.

column2: Mandaluyong was recognized as "The Tiger City of the Philippines" because of dramatic improvement in the city's economy.In 2020
column3: the city and the entire metropolitan Manila was placed under community quarantine for one month starting March 15 due to the 2020 coronavirus pandemic.

column1: According to Pedro Patricio in his book (Mandaluyong: 1837–1975)

column3: Barangka

column5: Namayan
column6: & Hulo) as per the first recorded census in 1903. From these five evolved 22 sub-barrios.

column1: Mandaluyong lies on a heart-shaped 11.06 square kilometres (4.27 sq mi) of land
column2: 7 kilometres (4.3 mi) southeast of Manila and 8 kilometres (5.0 mi) west of Pasig. To the south lies Makati
column3: to the northwest
column4: San Juan
column5: and to the northeast
column6: Quezon City. Thus Mandaluyong is located at the center of Metro Manila.

column1: Mandaluyong is politically subdivided into 27 barangays.
Mandaluyong's climate is classified as tropical. In winter
column2: there is much less rainfall in Mandaluyong than in summer. This climate is considered to be Aw according to the Köppen-Geiger climate classification. The temperature here averages 27.2 °C. In a year
column3: the average rainfall is 2093 mm. Precipitation is the lowest in February
column4: with an average of 8 mm. With an average of 448 mm
column5: the most precipitation falls in August. At an average temperature of 29.2 °C
column6: May is the hottest month of the year. January has the lowest average temperature of the year. It is 25.5 °C. Between the driest and wettest months
column7: the difference in precipitation is 440 mm. During the year

column3: commercial establishments
column4: high-rise offices
column5: residential condominiums and hotels. The city is one of the important business and financial areas in the metropolis.

column1: Like other cities in Metro Manila
column2: Mandaluyong has its own share of commercial strips and a central business district.
consisting mostly of banks
column3: offices and service establishments
column4: stretch along public transport routes thereby serving both local consumers and passers-by from the neighboring localities.

column1: Major commercial strips of the city include the stretch of Boni Avenue
column2: Shaw Boulevard

column4: Kalentong

column7: Sgt. Bumatay towards Barangka Drive and Pinatubo towards EDSA. Mandaluyong's central business district is concentrated on the EDSA-Shaw-Pioneer area.

column1: Industrial activities are mostly concentrated within the Shaw Boulevard-Pioneer area and along the Pasig River. Although prominent in the manufacture of foods
column2: medicines and laboratory equipment
column3: these industries are gradually declining in number
column4: opting to relocate in newly developed industrial zones outside Metropolitan Manila. In the Pasig River area
column5: particularly in Barangays Namayan and Mabini J. Rizal
column6: areas formerly industrial are now the sites for residential subdivisions and townhouses. In the EDSA-Shaw-Pioneer area
column7: the transformation is toward a more economically profitable and globally competitive commercial activity. And since December 2013
column8: Mandaluyong is the home of one of the largest television networks in the country
column9: The 5 Network (owned by TV5 Network located at the TV5 Media Center).

column1: These super-regional supermalls each have over a hundred local and international stores and are anchored by at least one department store and supermarket or hypermarket. They are also the largest malls in Metro Manila which feature not just stores but also attractions: movie theaters
column2: rides
column3: skating rinks
column4: bowling alleys and other recreational facilities. Each provides thousands of automobile parking spaces and are located mostly near rail stations and established business districts within the metropolis. These malls serve not only the Metro Manila and Greater Manila Area residents
column5: but also local and foreign tourists. Among the malls in the city are Shangri-La Plaza and SM Megamall

The city is provided with good access roads to and from adjacent cities in the metropolis. The city is served by one of Metro Manila's main roads such as the Epifanio de los Santos Avenue (EDSA)
column2: Ortigas Avenue and Shaw Boulevard.

column1: The city is 36 minutes away from the Ninoy Aquino International Airport.
Mandaluyong is served by the Epifanio de los Santos Avenue
column2: Metro Manila's main thoroughfare.  Considered as the heart of the metropolis
column3: main roads such as the Ortigas Avenue and Shaw Boulevard provide inter-city linkages
column4: while Boni Avenue and Martinez Street (C-3 Road) serve as alternate routes in the city. Other major roads in Mandaluyong include Boni-Pioneer Underpass
column5: a 280-meter long tunnel underneath EDSA (Epifanio de los Santos Avenue) connecting Boni Avenue on its western-end and Pioneer Street on the east. and Julia Vargas Avenue. Jeepneys are one of the most common modes of public transportation for commuters in the city. Aside from jeepneys
column6: tricycles and pedicabs are also one of the important modes of public transportation in Mandaluyong
column7: especially on alleys around the city.

column1: The presence of the Pasig River stretching along the south border of Mandaluyong provides an alternative route and mode of public transportation mainly for cargo freight of industries along the river
column2: and for commuters seeking for a faster and more direct route to and from the cities of Pasig and Manila. The Pasig River Ferry Service has one station in the city.

Mandaluyong has several private and public hospitals & health center

column3: and the government hospital Mandaluyong City Medical Center.  The city is also home to the National Center for Mental Health. Many residents
column4: specifically the middle-to-upper class medical clientele
column5: visit the nearby The Medical City in Ortigas Center.

column1: The Dr. Victor R. Potenciano Medical Center is a tertiary care hospital that has a 189-bed capacity within its 10-storey hospital building.

column6: and Assimilation of Children with Handicap (TEACH)

column1: Four well-known educational institutions in the city are the Arellano University
column2: Mandaluyong (Plaridel Campus)
column3: Don Bosco Technical College
column4: Jose Rizal University and Rizal Technological University.

column2: including incumbent Mayor

column4: Jr. (HS '79); former Vice Mayor
column5: Renato Santa Maria (HS '65); City Councilors Edward Bartolome (HS '96)

column8:
Francis Magalona (HS '81); and actor Ricky Davao (HS '78). Meanwhile, the alumni of JRU that includes President Ramon Magsaysay, Roderick Paulate, and Secretary Armand V. Fabella; 
Other colleges in the city include the Our Lady of Guadalupe Colleges (specializing in Medicine and Nursing), STI and AMA (both specializing in Computer Technology education, both located on Shaw Boulevard), NAMEI Polytechnic Institute (specializing in Marine Sciences), and the International Baptist College.
The city is also home to Lourdes School of Mandaluyong (est. 1959), a Franciscan-Marian all-boys school, located in the Ortigas Center district managed by the OFM Capuchins; La Salle Green Hills (est. 1959), a private all-boys high school, managed by the De La Salle Brothers, located along Ortigas Avenue; and Saint Pedro Poveda College (est. 1960), another all-girls institution, offering pre-school, grade school, high school, and college education. Although the official school address is Quezon City, part of the lot Poveda's campus stands on is under Mandaluyong City.
Mandaluyong High School (est. 1977) is the oldest public high school in the city. City of Mandaluyong Science High School (est. 1996), a public science high school on E. Pantaleon St. The city has 18 public schools, including primary and secondary schools as prioritize by the city government. The Mataas Na Paaralang Nepatli A. Gonzales is the largest school in Mandaluyong and the only school in the city which has the STEM highschool program. The Neptalians are also multi- awarded and has various great observations by the regional supervisors that captures their attentions.


== International relations ==


=== Diplomatic missions ===
Countries that have set up permanent missions or embassies in the city include:

 Malta
 Peru
 Slovenia
 Sudan
 Tanzania


=== Sister cities ===


== Official march ==
The official march of Mandaluyong is entitled Martsa ng Mandaluyong" and was composed by then Councilor Delfin Asistio during the incumbency of then Mayor Benjamin Abalos.
